book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship – part 1
author: K. Martens
solution_line: Order of tricks: 1. Win with the king of hearts. 2. Play the king of spades. If instead you run the heart lead to your hand and play a spade to the king, the opponent may duck.
result_comparison: Liechtenstein bid 4♠, +420 for EW. You preserved communications: -1 IMP. If not: -10 IMP.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship – part 1
author: K. Martens
solution_line: Order of play: 1. Duck the queen of hearts. 2-3. Win the next heart and play a diamond to 9 in the dummy. 4-5. Follow with ♠8 on South's spade switch and win with dummy's ace. Play the queen of diamonds.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3NT, +400 for EW. You remembered the safety play in diamonds: no swing. If not: -10 IMP.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship – part 1
author: K. Martens
main_technique: The saying ‘finesse is the essence of playing bridge’ is not always right.
key_insight: Finesse is the essence of playing bridge
solution_line: Order of play: 1. Win the trick with the ace of spades. 2-3. Play the ace and queen of clubs. I am not going to tell you anything else.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 4♥, +620 for EW. You played carefully: no swing. If not: -12 IMP.
additional_notes: Contract 4♥. Lead ♠3. South plays the king.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship – part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Be ready for your opponents' actions
solution_line: Chess problem – you have to predict what will happen. If you play a spade, the defenders will play two rounds of trumps. So, the only hope is a club suit. Play three rounds of clubs, ruffing in hand. Now you can concede a spade. The defenders are helpless. Ace and another trump will deprive you of spade ruffs but it will allow you to establish a club trick.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3♠ (NS) two off: +200 to EW. You ruffed a club before you played a spade: +790 = +11 IMP. If not: -9 IMP.
additional_notes: Contract 4♥. South opened 2♠. North doubled 4♥. Lead ♣Q.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship – part 1
author: K. Martens
solution_line: It seems that you will need trumps to be 2-2. Let's see how good South is! Order of play: 1. Duck the king of hearts. 2. east continues with the queen of hearts. Cover with the ace and South ruffs, which is exactly what you need. You now have an entry on the third round of trumps to two diamond tricks.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3NT, +400 for EW. You conceded a heart: +1 IMP. If not: -11 IMP.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship – part 1
author: K. Martens
opening_lead: ♣lead; three rounds of clubs, South throwing ♠4 on the third round.
key_insight: Protect yourself against the opponents' good defence
solution_line: You have to find diamonds 3-2 and the king with South. Is this the end of analysis? If we play straightforwardly a diamond to the ace, South may unblock discarding the second king. Maybe you should have won the second round of clubs. Stay cool, South is not a mind reader. South could have discarded the king on the third round of clubs. Play a heart to the king and a diamond to the queen. The opponents may still create a problem. South may duck a small diamond. On the net round of diamonds, east plays the jack. Where is ♦10?
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3NT, +600 for Liechtenstein. A diamond to the queen: no swing. Ace of diamonds: -12 IMP.
additional_notes: Contract 3NT. Lead – three rounds of clubs, South throwing ♠4 on third round.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship – part 1
author: K. Martens
solution_line: Order of play: 3. Ruff with ♥10. 4. Play a heart to the jack. If the trick stands: 5. Finesse the king of hearts. The contract will be made if the king of hearts is with South or if hearts are 3-3. The king of hearts doubleton with east is an additional chance (provided east plays high).
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 3NT, one off, +100 for NS. A heart to the jack: +620 = +12 IMP. If different: no swing.
additional_notes: Contract 4♥. Lead ♣2. Opponents play three rounds of clubs.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship – part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Shrewdness is one of the elements that needs to be trained
solution_line: Duck the seven of spades in both hands! South plays the four of spades on the first trick and east continues spades. Now you have a discard for a losing club.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 4♥ +420 for EW. How did it happen? Your team mates did not want to discuss it. You made the contract. east did not find the club switch: no swing. You did not duck the first trick: -10 IMP.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship – part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Keep the dangerous opponent off lead
solution_line: Order of play: 1. Duck the queen of diamonds. 2-8. Win the next diamond with the king, play ace and king of spades, ace of diamonds and four rounds of clubs, finessing. 9. Throw east with a spade. There is certain subtlety in this problem. If we find out that diamonds are 5-2 (for instance, South plays the jack of diamonds in the first trick) – east holding a doubleton, then we do not draw the third diamond but finesse clubs to the end.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 2♠, +140 for EW. You ducked queen of diamonds: +620 = +10 IMP. If not: -6 IMP.
additional_notes: Contract 4♠. North overcalled in hearts. Lead ♦Q.

book_title: K. Martens Virtual European Championship – part 1
author: K. Martens
key_insight: Do not give up. Try to find the winning line
solution_line: Ruff the heart and play the ace of clubs. It will be difficult to unblock an honour at this stage. Cash the ace and king of trumps, cross the dummy with a diamond and ruff a heart. Cash the remaining two diamond tricks and this is the position you will have: [complex ending position described with specific cards. K club and J98 Hearts with N]. Concede a club trick. North plays a heart, pitch a club from the dummy – South is hopeless.
result_comparison: Closed room – Contract 4♠ down one, +100 for NS. You cashed the ace of clubs: +620 = +12 IMP.If not: no swing.
